author: sinaigimenez
content:
Today I got a reminder of how important love and care are in what we do. Just wanna give a shoutout to @Nomograph Mastering for all the wisdom shared here on that topic.

Long story short — I agreed to mix a track for an American rapper who had already been turned down by some A-list mixers, even though the guy had a decent budget. The reason was kinda obvious: he’s got a personality that leans toward OCD, with everything that comes with that — defensive tone in convos, super long mix notes, and weird stuff like thinking a file sounds different just because it was renamed. (I forgot to label one file as “ref. limited” like the previous versions, and even though it was literally the exact same file, he swore the “non-limited” one had a different top end.)

Stuff like that made me seriously consider walking away from the project like the others did — I could just feel the back-and-forth drama coming. But after my first instinct, I remembered a lot of what’s been talked about here: love, care, and being open to the music and the art. So I decided to try empathy instead of just being a jerk out of frustration.

And honestly? It worked. After taking a bit of time to really talk to him and show I genuinely wanted to help — not just as a mixer, but as a human — I learned he’s totally burnt out and running on fumes 'cause he just became a dad. And I totally get that, since my first kid was born a month ago too. That connection shifted the whole vibe. The next round of notes actually made sense, and we ended up approving the first mix by version 4 — which isn’t bad at all. Happy client, job done.

Not saying you should hang onto toxic clients, but it was a solid reminder: don’t always go with your first reaction. Sometimes just showing a little care  about the person on the other side can change everything. It did for me this time. And tbh, I don’t think I would’ve handled it this way if I hadn’t read some of the stuff shared here. So thanks, y’all. This place is gold.

author: chrissorem
content:
Ruairí is rarely seen in public, but when he is, it’s usually at a stone circle, whispering into a reel of tape, or skateboarding through mist. He claims to live “between the 60Hz hum and the shimmer of 16k,” though some believe he’s simply in Killarney.

He meditates inside a Leslie speaker and only eats frequencies that end in 7.

author: chrissorem
content:
Here is where we are at so far: O’Flaherty is known for his unorthodox and borderline mystical approach to mastering. While some engineers rely on meters, graphs, and measurable science, Ruairí prefers to keep things mysterious under the hood — very mysterious. No one really knows what’s going on in the session file… including Ruairí. And that’s the point.

Most of his day is spent clicking on vaguely psychedelic images of your waveform and nodding slowly. Sometimes he zooms in, sometimes he just stares at the phase scope like it owes him money. Occasionally, he’ll touch a knob — but never the same one twice.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Have you ever received a gift from someone who is much more concerned with their experience of the gift giving than your experience of receiving it? They’ve fantasized about your response the gift and how it will make them look, want to control the way you open it, control your responses etc. it’s an extreme example but I think when we offer our gifts to the world we could do well to give them in as generous and unattached a way as possible. It’s not always easy or even possible, we are human. But there’s something very constricting about focusing on the response more than the inputs

author: LAPhill
content:
It's really hard to make decisions when you feel like our back is up against the wall. We've all experienced some degree of this, one way or another, and a lot of it comes down to personal tolerance for risk and resilience to weather dry spells, as well as our individual life circumstances.

There's no medal for going months without income. If you need to find a day job or side hustle to stay afloat, that's not failure. That's responsible. If the feeling of your wife's support is making you feel guilty, then it might be a signal to take some action to address that feeling. Music will always be there, and it's not an all-or-nothing proposition. 

I'm not trying to prescribe the way out of this, but give yourself some grace and permission to navigate it. You're not less-than because you take time to address your personal life and finances in the midst of building your career, you're human.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Ok, here’s another perspective based on some recent experience

Classic scenario that’s played out a thousand times. “What do you do?” - I work in music. “Oh, what exactly?” - I’m a studio guy, a Mastering Engineer, I finish records. “Oh! Have you worked with anyone I’d know?”

For the longest time the answer to that question was NO. And so the question felt like “Are you somebody?”

But now I can answer Taylor Swift. *Everyone* knows Taylor…

But you know what’s happened? I realized that what they were asking all along is “Am I somebody?”

They are working changing my oil or whatever and looking for a little berry on the tree, or a shell on the beach. Something to take home that day, something to lift them up a little. “I met a guy who does XYZ today”. I do it all the time. My neighbor drives the Mars Rover. I mean, she goes to work, logs in and drives the fucking Mars Rover. And that is amazing. And being proximate to it makes me just a little more special in that silly human way

So, a little empathy for the shell gathering normies

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Loving your job 80% of the time is a phenomenal, compared to the general public. 

One thing I’m amazed by working with Cian & Rollmottle is their endless capacity for positivity during a project. No matter how shitty my delivery or communication, they approach things with a smile and a sense of humor. I’ve literally never heard either of them complain. I thought commiserating about shitty aspects of a gig was a part of professionalism, but they have me rethinking things. 

In my own projects, when I approach clients with patience and curiosity, I find that not only are they happier faster, I’m happier the whole time. It’s SO MUCH EASIER to say “let’s try it” than to say “here’s why that’s not a good idea.” I find I learn a lot that way too. 

In any case, going back in to fix or add only bugs me when I think I’m supposed to be done. If I can stay open, then opening a session feels a lot easier. 

So I guess my advice is: you might have fewer problem clients if you try to remember they’re not problems to solve, they’re people to serve.

author: Slow Hand
content:
There's a term I came across years ago (cannot recall the source) that's always stuck with me. The writer made mention of people they called "geniuses of everyday living."

They were referring to the uncelebrated people among us who may be living quiet lives of private accomplishment. Not chasing after lofty or conspicuous goals, or a grand ambition. Perhaps these people are satisfied raising a family, or existing in their community to the best of their ability. Or perhaps they are absorbed in a far more humble pursuit and are completely satisfied in their day-to-day efforts.

That sounds like something to aspire to. And for those who might qualify I wonder how much intelligence or wisdom play a role in such a thing.

author: cian riordan
content:
"Sorry about the late night duplicate file, I did this track after six other people because I'm rushing as a team player.   I delivered as promised up front as we are all in overtime now to make it great.  *CLIENT* is happy with your work and with mine and we are all working overtime together.   Apologies also, I know there were some annoying ticks in there with some of the revised files. Still not sure why this one session did that. 

Of course I don't listen to every single file, post rendering.   We render and send 500-1000 files a month with the revisions on the 200-300 monthly songs that I do.  Team players don't ask such things on CC.  I work usually 7 days a week for 40-50 people a month, and making them happy with great masters is job #1.  Perfectionism is not a part of that process.    Software makes mistake, and that's ok.    People make mistakes and that's ok.   Mixes and masters should never aim for perfect, they should aim to connect, aim for humanity.  

Perfection is not the goal here, it's musicality and teamwork.  I'm sorry your ears suffered that horrible popping, but please, be cool. "

author: Zach Hughes
content: Story time. Last night me and my gf saw Janelle Monáe on her age of pleasure tour at the Ryman here in Nashville. While she was making her entrance on stage something weird happened to the sound. Loud pop, clicking, and then no signal, but seemed like the in-ears / on stage monitoring were still working. Her and the band played through the entire first song while everyone in the audience was just looking around confused. Many heads turning to the sound board. Eventually the crowd started a 'we can't hear you' chant and Janelle and the band realized what was going on. They all calmly walked off stage. Took maybe ten minutes for it all to get sorted with the sound. Then Janelle and her band proceeded to come back out redo the entire intro / first song and give maybe the greatest live performance I've ever witnessed. The show ended with a double encore. It felt like such an amazing example of class and professionalism. I got the sense that she decided, after walking off the stage the first time, that not a single person in the audience will remember this show being anything but amazing and it was. Truly undeniable. If anyone here has a chance to catch any of the remaining shows on her tour, I could not recommend it enough. 🤘

author: BatMeckley
content:
This is what I meant to say.
You’re probably not going to get a particularly serious or even accurate answer from most people to the “what’s great about you” question”. Best to ask trusted colleagues or third parties. 

For instance, having worked with Noah, his strengths as a producer outside of his obvious musical talent is his attitude with the artist. He’s, patient, kind, and authentically curious about what makes the other person great. A lot of people with his talent and odometer would go “do it like THIS”. He genuinely brings the idea out of the artist, which is rarer than you think, and also serves to make him better. It’s a neat recipe of humility making him stronger in the end. Fun to watch, and everyone leaves the session feeling better about themselves and the song.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
There’s a few questions there so one at a time I guess. I’m just going to answer what you asked directly, and maybe this week I can take a shot at answering what I think are the underlying themes..

**How do you approach your craft now, in terms of attention to detail**

Nothing has changed in terms of my attention to detail, everything gets the same love as it always did. The stakes for errors have gone up - when they are manufacturing 100k copies of vinyl then you have to be sure it’s error free

**Do you reject artists if they approach you to “Master my album i’ll pay you whatever you want” if you think the level of their sound might not honour your history with all these artists**

I don’t reject *anyone* who can pay my rate. I don’t vet clients on a “how will you make me look?” basis, I’m a service provider to them. There are very very occasionally mismatches where I’ll say “happy to do this but I think you’d be better served by XYZ”, an example being someone coming to me with EDM who wants really intense processing - another girl or guy steeped in that genre will serve them better

**How does it feel having a connection to these artists?**

It feels really nice to be trusted with people’s art, when someone like a St. Vincent says “yeah, this is good” it matters to me, she has great ears and taste so it feels good to hit a mark

It’s also very special to hear these things come out of the speaker for the first time - I’ll never forget hearing Nick Cave, or Taylor or Lana in the room for the first time. It’s a privilege to be trusted with their art

**but does it ever happen that you are wanting more?”**

I’m human and can be reliably trusted to do all the silly human things like being greedy, insecure, fearful etc. but every year I get a little better at living a better way, and around the music in particular my operating principles “The why” feel better and truer than they ever have

author: cian riordan
content: Eventually I caught the hang of things. I started to study the rhythms of the sessions, what order people would file in every morning. I knew the singer liked coffee one way, another guy did something else… I’d start to have that stuff ready. Instead of chumming it up with the band trying to fend off boredom while Eric was mid task, I stuck around on the couch… watching patiently. Those were the moments where he would start looping me into what he was doing, explaining his techniques. Before I knew it, I could start anticipating what he would need next. Someone mentions trying some vocals on a thing? I immediately got going on setting up a mic, getting headphones, even starting to dial in a mix on the headphone box. Percussion? Grab the trunk of junk and start laying out potential options. Once I started actually being useful, I’d be given real tasks. “Hey, do you think you could try doing a preliminary comp of this vocal?” I had been in the room for all the vocal takes, heard the discussion about approach and vibe, even made the singers coffee the right way… why not? That evolved into being trusted with recording stuff in the second studio… we were always running behind, and having me chip away at guitar tracking or re-amping was really useful. Years of this and we were a well oiled machine. I’d get looped into pre-production phone calls and meetings, he would start asking my opinion on things.. drum sounds, microphone choices.

author: LAPhill
content:
This feels like a good time to remind everyone to be careful about how much they share of their personal life on social media. I had a stalker that was a fan of a game I scored (surprisingly, the least-known thing I've ever done) start wishing my now-wife happy birthday on IG (she doesn't publicize her birthday and I would very rarely have her in posts). Then he made characters of us on his Wii. I eventually thought I had the situation cooled down, until he tagged us both, congratulating us on our engagement and knew when and where our wedding was, suggesting he might crash it.

I make a point of keeping my family out of any posts now, and don't show pictures of the area where I live, etc. etc..

author: oaklandmatt
content:
I'm totally with you on all this.

The question for me is less about the credit/ title, and more about the role. How do you get perspective at the end of the record making process? This role is changing, and we'd all be smart to understand where it's headed.

I get hired to finish songs a lot. Usually that means I have a "co-producer" credit. Sometimes it means "mixer" credit. Occasionally it's included "mastering." But really what I'm hired for is that combination of experience and technical knowledge. I'm an outside ear who knows how to fix what's missing. This role of "finisher" is really where a lot of the producer/ mixer/ mastering engineer profession is headed. The distinction between those roles is getting blurrier. 

Mixing engineers have moved from pulling up faders on the console and creating a mix (old school "mixers") to often just pulling up the rough mix of stems and making finishing touches (Jon, Manny, Serban, Tony, Bainz, etc.).

In this way, the "mixing engineer" profession is moving away from manipulating raw sounds to manipulating nearly finished mixes. This is sounding more and more like what a "mastering engineer" does. Now there's "stem mixing" and "stem mastering" too, further blurring the lines. These are all just slightly different configurations of the same thing. Who do you hire to get perspective and then act on it?

Those of us that are finishers or mixers or mastering engineers or whatever would be smart to think about how to adapt to the direction this is all headed. 

I want us all to win. I think we need to step back and expand how we think about the roles. It's the best way for us all to have careers.

author: Deleted User
content:
My humble opinion on this from a producer POV is that if the vision was compelling to me in the beginning from a foundational level, then it’s not done until everyone in the team feel good; and that includes myself. I always push to the point of it feeling as good as I can get it, then present it to the artist. I’d give them about a week or two to sit with it if they need to, if they love it then its a go- if they don’t and feel that what I did got in the way of their vision, I scrap it. 

If I took on the project and wasn’t fully on board with the vision, then I don’t go as far as I would normally go- but I still try to push it as far as possible and then let the artist decide

Rick Rubin’s A-B-C theory - If artist want’s A and you want B, then you need to find C that does both A and B. It’s not done yet

author: BatMeckley
content:
This is a pretty good encapsulation of what I’ve tried to Mr Miyagi here in this discord since I’ve joined. Virtually all the people I know that have made it work in this business have THIS in common. They might not all be compression wizards, they might not all play an instrument… there’s so many things different about them… but THAT duality seems to be the common thread of everyone I know who makes it (which again, is why I posted that  Noel interview). I can argue passionately about the difference between mics or even converters, the specifics of Bluetooth latency, and also truly believe in “just get to work”. I can relentlessly take the piss out of Cian and deeply respect him as a person and his talent at the same time.

I’ll admit I sometimes get bummed when it seems that a couple people read it as “oh, the trick is to be rude about someone’s Nan”, and it’s like no, the trick is to take music seriously and treat it as the magic gift that it is, while not taking ourselves too seriously and sucking all of the magic out of it.

Noel seems to encapsulate that better than I am currently.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
So I’m with Beckley on this. I get hired because of my taste, and I go into projects with full communication re: what is intended. 

I don’t say “this sucks I’m gonna fix it.” I say “I have some ideas about how to pull this into a really kickass place.” 

Very rarely as a mixer am I *only* mixing. Bass comes in and has no booty? Chances are I’m gonna be doing more than bx-subsynth to make it thump. Only tracked one guitar and it’s supposed to be huge? I’m gonna add some to really make that sell. 

I don’t always assume I know more than the artist, but the truth is, with the level of artists I usually work with, MOST of the time I do. 

That’s not an ego trip, it’s an understanding of the gig. It’s why people hire me. Why they ask for my help. And I treat that with deep respect. 

Last night Rauirí basically bullied me into buying RX standard for a project I was doing as a favor to a friend. I SPENT MONEY to do this thing. Because as Rauirí says: “Art matters.” 

And as Beckley ranted yesterday, I don’t think we should let something suck because we were only hired for a job. We’re not house painters who decided to fix a furnace. We’re general contractors who know how a house is built, and we fix shit that’s broken. (Bad example, but you get it.)

author: Slow Hand
content:
On reflection, the material benefits of *Option #1* are a nice selling point, but I think the bigger opportunity is to harness the superpower of rendering hit music at will. It would give me tremendous sway over the music industry once everyone comes to recognize that I can't miss. I would leverage that influence to make some positive changes where I can. Set up some institutions to cultivate and nurture the next generation of artists. 

Presumably, while the hit music I’m making runs counter to my personal tastes, it seems reasonable that it would still be valuable to *someone*. Just not to me. That will be my curse. I would dutifully churn out hits as fast as I am able to and gift humanity with a tsunami of unimpeachable pop awesomeness that will endure for a century. My sacrifice would be everyone else’s gain.

Counter-intuitively, by saturating the market with my personal brand of songwriting it would inspire the next generation of songwriters. Unable to compete with my torrent of sure-shot pop badness they would respond by writing new music that is the direct antithesis of my own brand of hits. With a little luck, the musical output of these writers would be exactly what I wished to hear all along.

That’s a win/win right there. I just have to suffer a bit. I choose *Option #1*.

author: LAPhill
content:
There was a line in The Assistant's Handbook that we were required to read at Berklee. Something to the effect of "the only people that will understand you are other engineers, and who would want to marry one of them?" 

In all seriousness, there are plenty of people that are doing this full-time that have partners and families. Speaking only for myself, my wife has zero musical background. It's frankly really nice at the end of a long day to listen to what she's been up to, or talk about any of the things we connect on besides music and turn work-mode off. The right person will understand your passion and support you, they don't have to live it themselves. But you also need to show up and support them in their own endeavors and interests. It'll make you a more well-rounded human.

author: Deleted User
content:
what are some things that you’ve been wanting to do outside of work life? 

I feel like the idea of “break” can look and feel different to many people, and I think the key is to find what version of those variations give you the most peace of mind and self acceptance. 

Personally, I have a few tendencies and mindsets around break that self-sabotages. things I listed below help me fight the self-sabotaging

1) going armadillo- when in extreme overwhelming state, you gotta find a way to get out of that. I get overwhelmed very easily, so I find that this is often needed. BUT, if you’re gonna go armadillo, then you wanna really commit to it until you feel a bit calmer and collected. Which leads to the next point 

2) sometimes I lie to myself that I’m taking a break but do a few spurts of work because I feel useless not doing work. I’ve learned that this needs to be avoided or else the “break” will be extended into a longer period of time, and I’d be doing little work here and there but also not get anything done properly. It takes a bit of commitment to take a proper break, and in order  to be able to commit to it - recognizing it as a part of maintenance routine to stay well functioning is really important in my experience. I am pretty bad at pacing myself and managing my own mental and physical wellness, so I am working towards being able to put the brake on early enough so that I don’t crash or skid away into a crash 😂

3) to deal with that feeling of feeling useless, I found that doing things that I wanted to do can help once I have gotten calmer by being in armadillo state for a bit. Getting straight back to work from here for me is extremely difficult, so I start with the combination of taking care of chores that got backed up from busy life and doing what I desire outside of work life. Could be trying a new restaurant, picking up a new hobby or getting back to the hobby that gone on hold due to work life

author: joshbonanno
content: i think the premise of this stems from the constant fight that i feel like we all face....wanting something to be the "best" it can be (at least in our personal minds and perspectives) vs the sometimes reality that we are hired to do a "job" and not everything is going to meet our expectations of what we personally think is great, because at the end of the day, we aren't the artist...or in some cases, even the intended audience. with that said...if someone is looking to hire me and my immediate gut says "this isn't great, everyone before me did a bad job and i am going to have to save the day" i immediately question if i am even the right person for the job as thats obviously not an attitude i really want to bring in to a collaborative process with others constantly thinking badly about everyone before me. / might mean i just dont understand the record itself. in the cases that i do take the job though, i typically just try and shift my mindset to think and assume that it made it to me this far and everyone signed off on it...so who am i to say its "bad" or needs fixing outside of what i was hired to do? maybe the bad vocal comps and slightly off time drums made it through the production stage because they liked the raw human nature of it? maybe their idea of life/color/mojo is different than mine and they're more sensitive to certain sounds etc....idk. this is maybe mainly more of a response pertaining to what i do as primarily mixing day in and day out and maybe doesn't translate as much to the production world...but i still think theres some connected ideas in that line of thinking. if the artist is happy with a sloppily played acoustic take that feels uninspired...you re-tracking and double tracking guitars that are on the grid and feel exciting to you doesn't always make it "better" in the artists mind or vision.

author: LAPhill
content:
The refresh rate on most TVs is slower than on a monitor, so you'll feel more latency. Even ones that do the hyper-real sports setting (motion smoothing) to display 120-240Hz will actually introduce MORE latency for that processing. 

If you can find a TV with a game mode, that's typically low-latency and you'd likely be fine.

author: Rob Domos
content:
I have a scalding hot take that the “indie girl” voice isn’t a fad and came about because it’s the optimal way to sing for the medium. 

Think of how opera doesn’t sound like human speech. That alien sound came about because extremely loose muscles create far less sympathetic intermodulation which sounds cleaner. It’s the same as how a speaker makes your desk vibrate and create out of time interference pattern distortions. Muscle tension creates hard surfaces that do the same when singing and opera singers obsess over undoing this. This is a big reason why so many of your favorite vocalists are opioid and benzo addicts. It’s not just culture. Downers are performance enhancing here. (Please don’t get any ideas artists) 

The modern pop voice is just maintaining that exaggerated opera looseness but with adaptations for the modern medium: English diphthongs instead of Latin ones, way less air in their lungs because the target is a foot from their mouth instead of 50 feet, and softened fricatives because a capsule right in front of the mouth harshly exaggerates fricatives. 

From a physics perspective it’s the perfectly optimized way to sing in 2024. You may not like it, but this is what peak performance sounds like

author: cian riordan
content: For a long time a struggled with any drum sound that *didn't* feel like you were the drummer sitting at the drumset. Now I find myself really leaning into more mono sounding drums and using hard panned effects like rooms mics and reverbs to give a sense of dimension but keeping the punchiness and coherency of the mono kit. It also helps makes the mix wider because things you pan L & R will have to fight with less density (~20hz -> 15khz!) from the drum signals.

author: peterlabberton
content:
Yeah… this is just me sharing my opinion, not trying to shit on anyone else’s: I am thoroughly uninterested in spatial/atmos. I’ve been able to listen in a few really swanky/certified rooms, to tracks that other more atmos-inclined folks were really pumped about, and I just thought it was gimmicky and—to my taste!—kinda lame. Not for any technical reason (though I have issues there as well), I just don’t care if a shaker sounds like it’s behind me and to the left or I’m *fully* enveloped in a reverb or whatever.

If I have to wrap my head around it to stay relevant, I’m fairly confident I can give my self a crash course—and if someone asked me to do an atmos mix and paid for the studio, then sure! But short of that… 🤷🏻‍♂️

author: cian riordan
content: I go back and forth. I finally got a decent turntable setup in the studio… calibrated, aligned, etc… and it was very interesting listening to analog and digital back to back. Most records I prefer the clarity and depth of digital, but there were a few (mostly from the 80s) where the analog pressing surpassed the digital. I still think the medium is a net positive in terms of music enjoyment and the collective industry, but I’ve moved beyond touting it as some sort of superior listening format. It’s just not. I remember mastering several records with Doug Sax and he would always joke with me saying, “you know there’s a better medium, right? Sounds better, is cheaper, etc”. Despite being the master, he understood how it’s evolved and had a sense of humor about it.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
When I was in high school, I played in a youth group band. We had wedges and I played guitar usually and sang. 

I remember like week three, I couldn’t hear myself during the service, and since we didn’t have talkbacks or even a monitor engineer, I just tried really hard to listen for myself. 

A second or two later myself was ALL I could hear. I thought someone broke the speakers. I looked up and around and nobody else seemed to notice. So I tried to listen for the other vocalists and all the sudden I could hear them too. 

Took years to hone that skill, and when I was touring I often said I was the worst player on the stage, but always the best listener. 

Truly, the human brain is remarkable at decoding things, and also at finding faces in clouds. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯ 

@itaylerner nailed it. Listen to what matters, and if someone else is chuffed over something that doesn’t, let ‘em have it with a smile and don’t let it get you down.

author: itaylerner
content: I don’t think it’s a way back, I think it’s a way forward to a new future. Music has been around longer than language, it’s not going anywhere. It’s human. But, this is late stage capitalism, and the internet / flattening of accessibility is probably the biggest immediate shift in human history. This world is all still VERY new and it will take time for us to learn what we’re doing and adjust accordingly. I don’t have any idea what it’ll look like, and I tend to get cynical when I spend too much time zooming out. There are times where it’s productive to intellectualize the landscape and try to understand things, but we can’t see the future, and that’s ok. The weight of this isn’t on us as individuals, it’s on everyone. So i just try to zoom in, make great art, do good, fair business, and do my part to contribute at each step of the way. Not really an answer to your question but I think about this ~a lot~ and this is the healthiest way for me to think about it without going crazy haha.

author: gatewoodsensei
content:
Schedule, schedule, schedule. I use a productivity app called Notion. Make multiple bottles ahead of time. That way you don’t have to stop working to make a bottle. You can pull them out of the refrigerator whenever you need, warm em up and you’re good to go. Most formula last at least 24 hours in the refrigerator. Breast milk is easier to work with because you can freeze it, grab it, and thaw it when you’re ready to use it. Plan your breaks around feeding. When he’s playing or napping, you can work. Make sure he’s visible tho. Have a bassinet, bouncer, or something next to your chair. Open backs help when mixing because you can hear if he cries. Babies love white noise. Play that shit on loop while he sleeps and he’ll be out for hours at a time. Use brown switches for your keyboard if you can get them. Those are extremely quiet and won’t wake the baby. 

That’s off of the top of my head. I might think of something else and add it here. CONGRATULATIONS!!!

I've never considered myself someone who's had substance issues of any kind (thankfully). I'm approaching the end of a self-imposed 3 month break from alcohol and as I near the finish line I don't feel as if I'm in any hurry to return to where I was.

I've been a casual drinker for over 15 years and recently have found that even 1-2 drinks the night before were leaving me feeling like shit in the morning, so I opted to remove them from the equation and see how I felt after my trial period.

author: chadwahlbrink
content:
I often use the proMB freeband mode as a basic “denoiser” for high end. 

If I get a vocal with some schmutzy noise, I will dip the high end, but have the lower vocal fundamentals trigger expansion back to a “flat” frequency whenever the vocal is actually singing. Release time to taste from there.

Can also help with an over resonant drum or lower “hum” issue where you want to dip most of the time, but then have it be “flat” whenever the snare hits, or whatever.

Comes in handy for post work too. Cleaned up a lot of VO’s and SFX recordings with those methods.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Last thing on the role of humor. I had an epiphany last year with my then-girlfriend. We'd been having a reoccurring friction in our relationship where she thought that I wasn't taking things seriously enough. Not everything, mind you, but there were certain scenarios where my humor was dismaying to her.

Eventually, what we discovered by accident one evening when exploring our personal values was that we both had very different understandings about the role and purpose of humor.

To me humor is a playground for creativity, trying things out, and testing ideas. It's play. To her, humor was something that she had come to know as a defense mechanism for defusing tense situations. She was very explicit about that.

As a result of these unvoiced beliefs there were moments where I was being playful and she would interpret it as me changing the subject or downplaying something. She thought I was being defensive. This difference in beliefs was hidden to both of us and it was leading us into frustration because we thought we had the same understanding of what something was.

I'm rambling a bit at this point, but It's always a huge relief when you manage to uncover the unspoken assumptions that you or another person are holding.

author: kieronmenzies
content: Hey this has been a fun discussion to read through. Just to add one more angle to the mix: most of you have been referring to agency as some kind of positive trait that you either have or you don’t have it — almost commodifying it. What if we think of agency, or the qualities of having agency no matter what term we use, as the norm? As in EVERYONE has it. And whether or not we are able to fulfill those qualities and/or desires is due to limiting factors, whether they are external forces (class system, institutional racism, gender discrimination, war, peer pressure, financial hardship, lack of resources, etc) or internal struggles (fear, self-doubt, depression, addiction, laziness, inner saboteur, etc) or any combination thereof. I know it’s totally idealistic but maybe if we’re able to think of everyone as being just as capable as the next -- instead of an “either-you-got-it-or-you-don’t” kind of way, especially in terms of “agency” which sounds like a corporate buzzword du jour -- then we’d be able to focus on and address the aspects of our societal constructs and daily lives that restrict our opportunities to succeed/work/create/thrive/survive/exist.

content:
As a former (what I would call pretty high level) athlete, I actually think about this thing very intently with regards to working on records and draw from things from the past life. Mine is more focused on how I want to hear (or rather deeply understand how I'm hearing) every day as close to consistent as possible, given we are human of course.

My 2 cents (which of course is just my experience): 

Some sort of routine before you work. Mine is that I wake up almost exactly at the same time every day, will work out at similar times (if possible), literally eat the same thing basically every day before during the work day, coffee at similar times, have  the same routine when I sit down to start work. Not all of that is possible or useful for everyone, but I think we can all find something that would focus us in a way that's useful and ablet to be put into practice for us.

Truly I find it helps a lot. We are physical beings, how our systems and bodies interact can definitely matter, especially in our ability to be available to the music.

That said, sometimes things happen and you gotta go. You will be tired, stressed, whatever. You have to do excellent work under those conditions too, it might be the most important skill if we are being honest about making a career of this. So training specifically for when you feel rough is definitely something I personally find important.  Which is where physically training helps, it's a way to force yourself into (fake) adversity and train response

@Slow Hand I know you know all this, just my experience

author: jonmatteson
content:
I do a lot of MD/live show building work and would advise against using a set up like this for a few reasons:
1. Having computers on stage is always risky especially when you don’t NEED it
2. There are better solutions for live guitar without using a $2000 computer. I use HX Stomps or helix on most gigs as well as kempers. These allow for midi changeable patches from playback as well as zero latency performance. Also they sound pretty great and have everything you could need in them!
3. If you use one of the above units you can back them up to your computer or thumb drive and in the event that one bites the dust, you can go buy one at your local guitar center and play the show instead of having to buy a new computer, authorize plugs, etc. 
Just my two cents!

author: frankieharper
content:
Thought for the end of the day… UK time 

Our arrangements and our mixes leap into existence from the womb of the metaphysical into a world rich in strict guidelines and predetermined boundaries. It’s drill, it NEEDS that thump… it’s lofi, it neeeeeds that blur, I want to get onto New Music Friday, it needs to be LoUd. 

Genre and playlists seem to rule with an iron fist… I often think that when an artist asks for a ‘brighter’ mix or an even MORE colossal 808. Not always… but often. 

Surely the overall and final sonic characteristic of our various musical expressions should be treated with as much emotional sensibility as our lyric or our narrative? 

Perhaps a dark lyric cries out for a dark mix… New Music Friday or otherwise?

Or is that built in?
 *wild generalisation hat firmly secured* 
Would it be too much of a reach to say that modern pop music is bright and loud because in recent history, pop music is high energy and bright in tone? Or is jazz historically observed from the back of a smoky leather bound room and so dark and dynamic just sits comfortably (whisky in hand) … I guess my question is… at risk of sounding a little Orwellian, do we control genre or does genre control us? Probably both? Asking for a friend.

author: Bonati12461
content: And sorry to bang on about this, but something that is critical to the audio quality on a record that is way out of most pro-audio people’s view is the state of the cutting lathe being used to do the master cut. Many people working in audio have never even seen such a machine. They are complicated - there are techs who work on consoles who won’t touch cutting lathes. IMO the best lathes were made by Neumann in the 70s/early 80s, and that was a long time ago. You have a TON of electronics and mechanics that need to be refurbished / restored to get the lathe to make some great cuts. Some engineers are cutting on some nicely restored systems and some are using some OLD stuff which should have been pulled for maintenance decades ago. Imagine if 50% of the records today were mastered on 50 year old loudspeakers with blown drivers and mismatched crossovers. We might notice.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Gosh, it can be so many things that endear me to an artist and it can be none of them. It's a slippery thing to grasp, but here I go:

**1. They have a well-defined vision for their art that I can observe them continually exploring.**
**2. If they present themselves as a public figure, what is the expression of their persona? **
Is it authentic? (I'm a real person)
Is it stylized? (a heightened version)
Is it larger than life? (I'm a God)
Is it mysterious? (Leave me alone)

**3. Their actions as a person**
What do they believe in?
What do they advocate for?
Does their sense of humor manifest in their art?
Do they have interests outside their music? Do they tie them into their art?

**4. How do I observe them confronting challenges?**
Do they swing big in their creative efforts?
Are they resourceful in how they execute?
Are they telling a story about these challenges?

These are all qualities that I like to observe in artists. Some artists will have all of them, some will have none of them, and that's alright.

author: Zack Hames
content:
I went to help a fellow engineer buddy record some drums today at his studio, and it made me think of something Jon Castelli said on the Conversations or LWMR podcast - he challenged the idea of being out of your comfort zone to grow, and look at the Benefits of the comfort zone.

My buddy is a great engineer and great drummer in a great and, so all great things. But his setup was just incredibly different than mine; he uses Studio One, I use pro tools (he’s also used to Pro tools and recently bailed on it). He’s using a combo of Antelope Discrete 8 and an Audient ASP880 and some good outboard pres (Vintech and Summit audio). His monitoring killed me, some small dynaudios which sounded okay and some ProAc’s. He had some decent mics. I brought my 8 Channels of UTA and a bunch of mics and was there just to put our heads together, and I was going mostly press record so he could drum for his bands record.

Anyway, we spent about 4+ hours trouble shooting Studio One, his computer, and the interfaces -eventually finding out one of his AD/DA channels was so messed up it sounded like a ribbon mic when it was a condenser. A lot of his mic stands and cables were really junky - he didn’t have enough of the basics on his own.

So many things were just not working as I would expect - my UTA preamps were set at much lower gains than I do at my studio because of his gear. I’m basically ear-blind because of the monitoring, even with headphones, and I’m working in Studio One so I can barely focus on the sound. And he used a normal Apple mouse, I use a trackball. 

Im trying not to complain, but it just blew my mind how much of an uphill battle recording can be just because of simple things being so taxing. We spent about an hour of the 6 hours I was there tracking one song. The rest was setup. It made me realize why we put so much work into making our process simple and getting gear that is effective and reliable.

author: ALXCPH
content:
For the kind of chops that your description seems to hint at, i would say it is all about tieing technique to your ears. (Assuming, you can already hum a melody on the spot and are not tone deaf) 

I wouldnt worry too much about theory and super correct technique. 

The best Way to get anywhere on an instrument is by Playing it, and doing in consistently. Set some realistic goals and just get going, vocabulary and technique Will come naturally if you just keep Playing. 

Fuck Playing scales and inversions and all that for now. 
Just go learn a metric ton of songs and melodies and learn to play them together. Do it by Ear. It Will be tough in the beginning, but you Will get very decent quickly if you just do the most important Thing, which is being consistent.

I would reccomend setting a low minimum to do everyday to keep a realistic goal that you can keep, rather than a higher on you miss every now and then. You can always add more practice but it sucks to miss out on it.

Start with song you want to Sound like and then you can slowly branch out when the style become second Nature for you. 

Sadly there are no tricks or hacks or whatever youtube wants you to beleive to get their clicks. Its all about muscle memory and developing your ears together. And not to Sound like 4 bar loop, but consistency, and do it a lot. I cannot stress that enough. ❤️

author: shaunobi
content:
@Jeremy Klein some thoughts on home ownership... my wife and I have done pretty well on our house. We've got a large one for our kids (3 kids, my dad also lived with us when we moved into our current house, so 6 people total) and we do plan to downsize if / when they move out. Current rate is 2.65 (I got a good deal, and spent a little to buy the rate down at the time - payoff on that was like 7 years).

We kept the old house, and for about 6 months I considered renting it out. I did not enjoy being a landlord, though, and abandoned mission quickly on that. I'd definitely go the prop manager route if I was to even attempt it. Portland rental scene ain't great though.

Prices in Portland specifically... if you chart them out, the more expensive houses aren't doing great, some zip codes aren't doing great, but in general anything in that "starter home" range that's also near a decent school has done pretty well.

In terms of investing in S&P 500 or total market or whatever, I think you can pretty easily see that they're more correlated than not these days. That was the big thing about the housing crash - RE crashed along with the market crash. In the past those could be decorrelated, so "diversification" worked in your favor. Housing crashing? Rebalance into stocks. Stocks crashing? Rebalance into RE or REITs. Truthfully, though, that's just not the case anymore. Nothing is safe 🙂

I think there's also some psychology here. You can run the numbers, and they do pencil out at times in favor of renting (and I do intend to rent at some point in the future, though I've mostly owned a house). However, being a bit "house poor" sure is a good way to do some forced saving. For years my wife and I paid an extra $1k a month toward our house, and had a very low rate, and we really saw our net value go up quickly. It was nice.

One final thought... you often make money on RE when you buy, not when you sell. Place I'm in (which is in a nice part of Portland up on the Alameda ridge) wasn't selling, and I offered $80k under list, and got it. Put $80k into it in improvements (had an ugly small kitchen) and it's worth a lot more now.

Overall tho? I'm mixed. Bad neighbors suck and you feel stuck with them. Maintenance is a killer (3% a year is about right IME). Sometimes you just don't want to deal with problems. But then... renting sucks too in other ways. Choose your poison! 🙂

author: Zach Hughes
content:
That's a great question. Does a balance need to be struck? I think it comes down to what we believe about our role in relation to the people we are working with. To someone who doesn't work much with other people to whom success is largely predicated on their lone creative genius maybe the question of balance is neither here nor there.

However, if you are on a team, are a leader, teacher, or coach suddenly you are on the hook with others and the performance of the group matters. The highest achievement, future funding, drawing in more talent, etc... might all come down to the performance of the group. Would it then be wise to be so laissez-faire about undermining the intrinsic motivation / confidence of others? What if an unintended consequence of that attitude is less actual human connection?

Last thought I had is how do we know the truth of someone else's potential? Fwiw I don't know the answers but this is what's kicking around my head.

I do the boring business structure stuff before getting into new year visions. Doing things like inventory helps set the vision. Updates to the spreadsheet for things sold and things bought. author: peterlabberton
content: I typically go for a blumlein or ortf-ish setup as it just sounds more coherent to me. The one thing that I’ll do pretty frequently, and if I’m going for more exaggerated width, is what I think of as the Nigel Godrich technique: one overhead dead center, and two spread real wide basically over the cymbals. If you watch the From The Basement videos, he’s always got a U47/48 in the middle and Coles on the sides. You angle the sides so the opposite side of the kit is in the null. Super wide, and then you have the mono sound from the 47. I love this setup and do it a lot if I have the time/don’t get lazy and just put up an r88 or something and call it a day.

author: Adam Thein
content:
My main tip for using Live live is try and replace as many third party plugins as you possibly can with stock, freeze as much as you can, and most of the latency you experience is going to be coming from internal delay compensation vs I/O latency.  If you are able to optimize your sets as much as possible, you can probably get away with running everything without offloading DSP to a UAD system.  If you are already in that ecosystem by all means!

I built a live set similar to what you have going based off of Daniel Mintseris Lynda (now LinkedIn Learning) videos that were amazingly helpful.  Also in my case I made samplers whenever possible of 3rd party synths if the patch didn't have a ton of modulation internally.  But yeah bottom line is keep an eye on your total device latency on groups (hovering over a group will display the total delay compensation/latency calculation in the Status Bar).

If you have any other questions for me feel free to DM!

Edit: we used a rackmount X32 for in ears that also served double duty as the audio interface running 16 i/o at 48khz and were able to do it on a 2015 macbook with minimal latency

author: Slow Hand
content:
Strongly second all of this. Watch your accumulated plugin latency like a miserly hawk and do what you can to use Ableton stock plugins when you can because they are incredibly stable within the DAW and the last think you want is A) for your session to crash during a show and B) you don't want to be troubleshooting a fussy set that was working fine yesterday when you have to be onstage in 15 minutes. That'll make you sweat bullets for sure. Been there.

Also *yes* to the Daniel Mintseris Ableton live set videos. If you're seriously considering using Ableton on stage with live instruments it's rich in strategies for streamlining an elaborate performance set.

author: ALXCPH
content:
Yes. The same way you do anything in life you want to get good at. Spend a shit load of time doing that thing. There really are no hacks or work arounds if you want to actually get good. An easy free way to do it is just learn as many songs as you can. If you want to really be proficient in the musical language I would recommend learning stuff by ear. It takes a lot longer than looking up tutorials or sheet music. But I promise you will develop your ears infinitely more. Specially in the beginning. Music is a language. Every human being learns to speak and converse before they learn how to spell and know the rules of grammar. Learning theory will only let you put names to sounds so that you can convey musical ideas to their people. Contrary to what a lot of people think, there are no rules, but there are a lot of conventions and traditions, but they keep changing and have lots of exceptions. Learning a shit ton of songs on whatever instrument you choose, will teach you what those conventions are and how to use them. 

In the beginning it’s good to just learn every song you like as well as you can, because it will help keep you motivated as you like the music. Then after a while you will probably want to branch out and try stuff you’ve never listened to or enjoyed before just to challenge yourself. 

The most musical people I know, are the people who wouldn’t know what to do with a Caugmented#9 but can listen to a song once and play it nearly perfectly, because their ears and musical language is so developed from playing a fuck lot of music and not spending time reading about it or watching endless tutorials.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
I’ve been using a nice workflow for AirPod checks recently.

1. Have an output from your monitor/output bus (I have it on a send in my template) to PT Bridge

2. Open QuickTime and open a new audio recording (Cmd + shift + N). 

3. Select PT Bridge as the QuickTime audio input. Turn up the volume slider to monitor

4. Select AirPods as system output 


Hey presto. Works great, no need to stream to phone etc. Just have to remember to turn down that QuickTime volume slider when you flip back to speakers. Also I occasionally accidentally start QT audio recording with spacebar when meaning to hit play in Tools. No biggie 🤷🏻‍♂️

author: Deleted User
content:
@joshbonanno said:

i think the premise of this stems from the constant fight that i feel like we all face... 

wanting something to be the "best" it can be (at least in our personal minds and perspectives) vs the sometimes reality that we are hired to do a "job" and not everything is going to meet our expectations of what we personally think is great. 

because at the end of the day, we aren't the artist. In some cases, even the intended audience. with that said, if someone is looking to hire me and my immediate gut says "this isn't great, everyone before me did a bad job and i am going to have to save the day" i immediately question if i am even the right person for the job as thats obviously not an attitude i really want to bring in to a collaborative process with others constantly thinking badly about everyone before me. 

/ might mean i just dont understand the record itself. in the cases that i do take the job though, i typically just try and shift my mindset to think and assume that it made it to me this far and everyone signed off on it. 

so who am i to say its "bad" or needs fixing outside of what i was hired to do? maybe the bad vocal comps and slightly off time drums made it through the production stage because they liked the raw human nature of it? maybe their idea of life/color/mojo is different than mine and they're more sensitive to certain sounds etc....idk. 

this is maybe mainly more of a response pertaining to what i do as primarily mixing day in and day out and maybe doesn't translate as much to the production world. but i still think theres some connected ideas in that line of thinking. if the artist is happy with a sloppily played acoustic take that feels uninspired...you re-tracking and double tracking guitars that are on the grid and feel exciting to you doesn't always make it "better" in the artists mind or vision.

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content:
Not shit talking BBC, or my own products... but on a BIZ TIP for younger me out there: Don't assume there is no reason to push for players because you have great sequencing skills and $50k worth of sample libraries.  When the production company wants world-class sound, and it's your job to create the budget...   knowing that sample libraries can only take you so far is key to explaining to the client WHY they should allocate budget for humans. "I can create this with just the computer, and it will sound great....  but it won't sound like your example.  There's a real VALUE to humans playing the music and that extra 10% of the quality you're looking for requires a studio session with real players" 

Instant path to budget upgrade.  Suddenly the expense makes sense to them.  Now you get the pleasure of hiring all your friends and deliverying something that sounds top notch...  and you can take the client on a mind-blowing field-trip.  It took me years to learn this trick...   clients don't want to pay mountains of money extra for you to sit in front of your computer and massage CC lanes....  and if they have a mindblowing time in the studio and the track sounds ALIVE?  You win six different ways.

author: Slow Hand
content: @Dodgy One reason for the specific listening levels that are being mentioned are because of what are called Fletcher-Munson Curves. The gist of it is that we (humans) hear a balance of frequencies differently depending on how loud or how soft the sound is. This affects our ability to accurately judge what the actual balance of a record's frequencies are and make good decisions about a mix. These researchers (Fletcher and Munson) did a lot of research and came up with a chart that shows how our perception of sound changes depending on how loud a sound is. The general takeaway from looking at these results is that we perceive sound as closest to neutral/flat when listening around 80dB and thus it is the least compromised level to listen at.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Yes, for my needs it absolutely is. Though I can totally understand how it can become a time suck for people who enjoy the feeling of being busy. There's a *lot* of productivity porn out there.

I've been managing a small business for the last 5 years and it's a lot of information to keep track of. Notes, thoughts, ideas, receipts, photos, payroll, reminders, plans, parts, etc. Often I need to recall stuff that happened 8 months ago and that requires me to be meticulous in my organization.

On top of that, I'm ramping up into work with a second company that has the potential to draw on every single skill set and interest that I have. Having the tools to draw disparate connections between my past knowledge and the new ventures with this company could be a huge multiplier for what I can do. It's currently helping me to map out the idea space for this company and really get a big picture of everything that's going on.

I'm a big believer that human memory is fallible and prone to unwitting revisions and mis-recollections that distort events. Even in ways that are benign. Every read is a write. So it's important to unload the important stuff in a place where it won't spoil and distort with time. You could say I'm big on long-term memory and a bit weak on short-term memory.

I'm also a glutton for information, and offloading things and storing them "externally" allows me to unburden myself and not get overwhelmed by it all. I consider a lot of what I do to be trading in information and drawing connections. Some of my long-term personal projects revolve around topics like slow, imperceptible, change and there's simply no way to begin to observe that stuff unless I have rock-solid documentation and data that I can call on twenty years from now.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Not an answer to your question, but reminded me of a dynamic that I observed in my time assisting at major London studios:

There was a noticeable number of US clients (artists + their entourages, certain producers, and especially writers - usually in pop or hip hop) who treated assistants like “the help” / waiting staff / taxi drivers / some menial worker they felt was beneath them. The first few times it happened, it was kind of shocking, and very off-putting.

Of course there are going to be bell ends from every country (and there were plenty of exceptions - I've had many incredible sessions with North American clients, and some gross sessions with UK clients too), but it happened enough to wonder whether maybe it's a cultural thing?

Does this hold water with you US folks’ experience? FWIW, I can’t imagine anyone in this Discord treating anyone like that, let alone their colleagues. And of course, my personal experience is probably weighted 80/20 UK/international.

author: austenballard
content:
> There was a noticeable number of US clients (artists + their entourages, certain producers, and especially writers - usually in pop or hip hop) who treated assistants like “the help” / waiting staff / taxi drivers / some menial worker they felt was beneath them. The first few times it happened, it was kind of shocking, and very off-putting.

I want to add to what Ruairí and Matt B said with another perspective. I've had the privilege of working in some very professional settings, where everyone needs to fade into the background to do their jobs properly, and that's absolutely the case at higher levels. And it makes things work. And everyone's cool about it.

But much of my work has been as producer, assistant producer or project manager/fixer for people working at decidedly lower levels. 

And idk how it is in other countries, but we have a glut of people here in the US who have a certificate from a for-profit recording school that says they know what they're doing, who think they're *the shit* for being in the room with some viral star off YouTube/Instagram/TikTok. But don't know how to use a damn patch bay. 

And when you're on the come up, especially as a writer or producer, you interact with a lot of these people, and you get REALLY sick of them REALLY fast. So that might be the source of some of the condescension you see. It's hard not to get jaded when you have to wade through so much incompetence. I feel like a bitter old man just typing this paragraph tbh but I hope I'm not the only one with this experience.

author: Deleted User
content:
This can be controversial, but to execute C no matter what artist says or wants to do and present it. That way they can at least have a tangible result to compare it with. Instead of explaining, it’s better to do it and show it.

My humble take: our job is not necessarily doing what we’re told. it is to take their vision, and take it to a place where they could say “wow- I didn’t know this is what I wanted but this is what I want now”. Which I think is the taste and perspective factor. 

It is case by case of course and some artists could come in with A to Z manual of what they want, which can be cool- or not. I personally find those boring, unless I really admire their vision and it just feel like an honor to be a part of it. I think being a yes man can be a quick way to become dispensable. But someone who is willing to serve by giving you some friction that can turn into some heat 🔥 can be someone they find trustworthy and interesting. It’s case by case dependent, some people need perfect aerodynamics to accelerate their vision, and I don’t think that’s necessarily being a yes man- but rather about just being the right fit for the project and being someone who is fully on board to do what they are asking. 

But I think more importantly- it’s okay to miss. If they don’t like it - then scrap it or give it another go. And it’s also fine if you end up not being the one for the project

author: Slow Hand
content:
I'm particularly keen on this idea of humor as lateral thought. I've got a motto that I say to myself as a matter of process: "Always invert."

Whatever the subject facing me: a problem, a reply in a conversation, an object, a principle I'm adopting, a rule, or an idea, always start by inverting it's properties and seeing what you get. Turn it upside-down and see what that extreme reveals to you, then make a choice.

Often, with an inversion of perspective you get something hilarious, and that can be valuable in it's own right, but just as often you get newfound empathy, or something unexpected, or catch yourself from stumbling into a foolish move. Although, quite often the inversion itself *is* the foolish move because it flies in the face of common sense. 😄

author: cian riordan
content: A big reason I like the Grace M905 grabbing my computer output digitally as well as the output of my PT converters digitally. That way, things are showing up at 0dBFS from both sources, while also feeding my metering through the same path (Clarity M + spectrum analyzer). With Spotify you need normalization off and volume at full — ideally you’d have Tidal and force control over the DAC and bypass core audio, but I’ve got no gripes with Spotify at this moment.

author: Deleted User
content:
Fair enough. Everything that concerns “me” starts with working on myself. 

But my belief as someone who makes art; it is my job to be concerned about it, and spend time pondering on it. I’m not responsible or I can’t be for it, it would be an arrogance and narcissism (or ego centric frame of mind at the very least) to believe that I’m responsible for it or matters in any way - but I think believing that what I do would have no impact on others is inconsiderate. 

I believe it would help people find things they like if everyone alivned their taste/values to their individuality; rather than the idea of their individuality.

Re: Korea; 
you bring up a very good point about this. Korea is an extreme case of collectivism over individualism, and my obsession about this probably stems from growing up in that background. I only truly understand two cultures from first hand experience and that is Korean and North American; but it seems that no matter how culture forms, human nature will always be relevant and it’s in our nature to be want to be accepted, feel included. 

I believe that American individualist propaganda is a lie. It’s not about being yourself, it’s rather about finding a box to put yourself in for sake of convenience. i believe it mostly has to do with consumerism and the complexity of the society from immigration and various cultures coming together; converging / diverging at different pace even amongst those that share the same cultural roots- which then later becomes nu-gen X-American culture, which is different from the culture of X. (X being a country/ethnic group)

author: Chase H
content:
nice!!! The big takeaways I get  from Kant are him pointing out certain preconditions for the possibility of experience/knowledge at all.
 If those preconditions aren’t the case then experience itself is impossible.
In short, if one’s worldview denies the possibility of the things needed for experience or knowledge to be possible, then that person can’t even make knowledge claims at all without being self refuting

He was trying to respond to Hume after David Hume tried to nuke Metaphysics. 

Kant like other German idealists is a reallt dense read, a philosophy teacher on YouTube named Daniel Bonevac has some great videos on Kant that distill it down into way more palatable things to chew on if you felt like it.

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content: Seriously though....  this was inspired by a pop track string/winds  arrangement.  You'd think "well of course all the sample libraries I bought can do that just as well"  but not imxp....  its that the sample libraries can do "an adequate" job and satisfythe need.  But once you hire world-class players and play it live into mics....  for me it was instantly "we could've bought every sample library and programmed for days but never gotten this quality" in the tiny details.  The bow sounds. The players breathing together. Their adaptation to dynamics. The aleatoric sections where advanced techniques were improvised. Samples can be amazing and do things humans can't...  but the inverse is also true.  There are many context where it's got to be live players, or else your track is just "adequate"

author: Adam Thein
content:
Found this

“I took the head off a snare drum and started whacking it with a wooden ruler, recording it through a Shure 57 microphone,” he says. “As I did that, I started twisting the hell out of the [API 550] EQ around 1 kHz on it, to the point where it was starting to sound more like a crash. I blended that with a snare I found in the Linn itself, which was a 12-bit machine, so it sounded pretty edgy to start with.” But the coup de grace for the sound was when Z pumped the processed and blended sample through an Auratone speaker set upside down atop another snare drum, which rattled the metal snares and gave the result some ambience and even more high end. The whole thing was limited slightly and then sent to a track on a roll of Ampex 456 running on a Studer A800 at 15 ips. Only a slight amount of reverb was added to the track later on.

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
Timbaland’s talent and contribution to music is something I cherish. Sad when someone of that influence has a take this off base.

I believe the most valuable creative currency of the coming era will be authentic innovation of expression. Creating music that is ahead of the curve of expressing the human experience in a way AI couldn’t have previously copied, since it’s so true to that artist then as a representation of where they are at that time based on all the influences leading up to the moment of creating that art.

There’s always been a flood of copies after something fresh is made, and I believe AI will make it easier for people to follow-up with products like that, but the forefront is too imbued with the energy of the lived energies zeitgeist to be emulated by code - Perhaps one of the few things that code will never be able to do.

I’m open to being wrong, but that’s the thought this gives me.

author: MosesSOG
content:
I rather enjoy this question. Strategies to stay optimistic in 2026. 1-is a compelling vision! A a vision of the future that is exciting and has enough "impetus" or "unction" behind it to get me excited about the work i am taking on and gives me a thorough enough reason to wake up every day. 
2. - consistent prayer and a meditation practise. taking time to do things to ground my self spiritually. i also consider in thiss area study, and fasting at times, and even deliberate training and nourishment - essentially those things which benefit a spiritual life and overall well being
3. living in awe, or allowing yourself to be amazed. intentionally finding things that speak to me or captivate my mind. it is a continuous journey sometimes what used to inspire no longer does so regualy finding things that light my mind up.
4. collaboration/ contribution to a collective whole. there is nothing better than creating something awesome with afriend or brother. that is something that i do take great delight in. creating in a solitude - there is a time and place. yet if i am not connecting with people i love then it feels empty.
5. rejoice. be merry. taking time to celebrate. realizing all of this can be gone. so doing my best to keep that in my mind. there are people in much worse situations, no matter how hard it gets. and there are people who currently wish they had what i had.

author: antoniohannamusic
content:
Hey Rob, so I did a video explaining it (using the older version of the plugin) but in short you create two sessions, an Artist Session and a Producer Session.

The Producer session: Sends full mix + click to artist and has a receive channel

The Artist Session:

Receives full mix, then sends back the performance dry (vocal, guitar, bass, trumpet, you name it)>

In the producer session you then offset your local playback by the roundtrip latency, so you're hearing the artist perform "in time" with your session,

You then just nudge the clips back after each take 😄

author: David Fuller
content:
Anyway: uncompressed PCM audio (.wav and .aiff) is made up of digital words generally 16 or 24 bits long recorded however many times a second for a given sample rate, for fixed point (integer) values. Each bit represents ~6dB of dynamic range. Every time you go up in level 6dB from that particular sample point, another bit flips from 0 (off) to 1 (on). The least significant bit defines your noise floor, so 16 bit audio has 96dB of dynamic range at maximum from noise floor to full scale (every bit turned on). Seems simple enough, right? And it isn't super complicated. But it has one problem: you run out of dynamic range real quick if you're changing levels with (virtual) faders at 24 bits. There are two ways around that:
1, make the mixer engine run on a much higher integer word length (like old Pro Tools HD systems, which use 48 bit integer), and the mixer automatically converts the audio (if anything is done to it, including fader moves) to 48 bit. Think of this as adding more digits to the fractions side of a decimal point. 
2, make the mixer engine run on a floating point system (almost every other DAW, including more modern versions of Pro Tools) - that is, you move *where the decimal point is* . 32 bit float effectively works as 24 bits that can be moved around more or less with impunity, up or down.

author: dylannash
content:
What are some of your favourite elements of your prod/mix templates? I currently have a separate production/writing template and then another for mixing but I’m trying to hybridise and streamline them a little more to get faster results and hopefully focus on the song. Also, most of the songs I mix tend to be one’s I’ve written and produced as well, so hoping to cut down on session set-up time.

Some of mine are an instant “duck bus”, which I picked up from Ian Kirkpatrick. It’s a pre-loaded aux with something like LFO Tool or shaper box on it, so you can quickly route and uniformly make things side chain.

Another quick workflow thing I love is having Pro Tools audio playlists with a bunch of reverse sweeps, impacts and other transition fx/ear candy hidden and ready to go in the session, so you can quickly try out a bunch. 

I also have the trim plugin added as the first and last plugin on every new track preset, as I use them to quickly manage the gain in and out of each track and so I don’t have to search for them constantly.

Ozone Spectral shaper on some music busses and as a replacement for Soothe on the mix bus has also been a real win (thanks Jon!) Although these sorta things aren’t turned on whilst writing as they have a ton of latency.

Keen to hear what you all find useful!

author: skinnybreakfast
content:
Sorry for the book incoming. But this is plaguing my mind. Has there been an in-depth discussion on live or in discord yet about musicians on tiktok? 

It's a crazy scene of selling your creative soul for 1 minute of attempting to go viral. and then if you do get a popular video, whatever that one was - that is now your thing... singing into a trash can doing RHCP covers... ok, now do another 100 of those.  I see so much talent on there, genuine talent and artists who have worked hard on their craft getting 10 views due to the algo... once the algo has tried your vid on a few people and it didn't stick the vid is dead... so it's totally hit and miss based on your first small sample of viewers.

I see this having a huge impact in many ways. On the plus - you are getting exposure to incredible new ideas, skills, trends, methods for being creative... on the negative it's demotivating to the nth degree, and cheapening the creative process, in my opinion.

Matt and Jon recently talked about track lengths getting shorter and shorter, now 2 minutes is the normal. Partly due to the attention span of people... well what is this going to do... 1 minute pop tracks incoming? Just gimme the hook in 30 seconds and let's move on please. :p. How can we get young people to lay on the floor and listen to 10 minute vinyl tracks again? In my opinion humanity NEEDS this :)) 

I also swear I've heard the influence of trending memes from tiktok coming through in music in the charts, but cannot really back this up.

What's everyone else's thoughts? I have a friend in LA who says everyone has gone crazy there for tiktok fame? 😛

author: hendrick
content:
I agree with matt that hiring a mastering engineer is a luxury in the present day tbh. Most of the records that I get to mix or produce I'm expected to deliver a finished product ready to release. However when a lot of things are at stake (label release) it's almost 100% sure that a mastering engineer will take care to finish the record, do some QC and especially keep a human touch to the art. Would a co-mixer be able to do that? possibly, depending on their skillset/experience.

with the use of AI and other systems the expense of hiring a mastering engineer is already fading away but only for projects that are less risky. Say, if you have a tape library of 500 symphonic recordings and need to submit it for streaming so a few folks can listen to it, labels will most likely get an automated system for that to make sure that the standard levels are ok and that it translates well. I'm sure there would be a hungry mastering engineer willing to get that done but the industry is past that era

I’m coming to an impasse; I’m in a band that works a lot and I record our stuff, and I get a lot of work Mastering and Mixing. The more I do that the more I realize that the production and tracking are significantly more important than MIX/MSTR for the “success of the song”.

author: Jeremy Klein
content:
To me what is so fascinating about this GPT era of AI is that it's replacing skills in the exact opposite order that virtually everyone thought it would just 5 years ago.

Everyone thought AI would replace humans in this order:
pure physical labor -> low skill labor like truck driving -> medium skill work like HR -> high skill work like coding, medicine, etc -> LASTLY art and anything creative

author: Slow Hand
content:
I think a good example of someone who represents that shift is the painter Mark Tansey. 

His paintings, while photo-realistic, don't derive their value from their resemblance to the real world. Instead their interest lies in their allegorical representation of people and places. Their unique value lies in the curation of ideas and the story, concept, or idea that they convey. They're telling a pretty sophisticated story under the surface.

Look at these paintings. There's no individual element of either of these that I couldn't render right now with Dall-E and photoshop my own remake together. But right now AI is nowhere close to creating such a cohesive visual composition with it's unspoken message. For now great art still requires a human operator with intention.

author: Rollmottle
content: AI ain't shit without human intervention. It's just another means to an end, another arrow in the quiver.

author: LAPhill
content:
Given the exponential levels in advancements we're already seeing in AI, I think anyone who thinks what we do can't be replicated in a few short years might be fooling themselves. But the thing that can't be replicated is the audience's connection, right? 

Growing up, when there was music I liked, I latched onto everything I could about the artist. I digested as much as I could about who these people were, what they looked like, what they wore, what guitar they played, etc. etc.. Audiences are still going to seek a connection with other people, it's human nature. I don't think we can ever replace that connection with an AI. Until falling in love with robots becomes normalized, and then we have bigger problems.

Oh not utopian in the philosophical all is perfect sense, utopian in the post capitalist way. It’s a general term used in the development of things.
