author: Slow Hand
content:
It's crazy to revisit all of the things that you've forgotten. Every once in a while I'll randomly pick a journal entry from fifteen years ago and discover that I had some *raw* feelings about an old girlfriend or someone who I might look back on fondly now. I was *super* pissed at them, or I was very immature in my thinking, or I was full of so much joy. Old emotional layers that have long-since been painted over and forgotten. You really get to see how far you've come. 

I don't dwell on those feelings, but observing the changes can be illuminating or humbling.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Had an interesting realization with my ex a few months back that was illuminating. She kept insisting that I don’t take things seriously and that my humor was a defense mechanism, something I strongly rejected.

With some discussion what we were able to uncover is that we actually had very different perspectives on the role of humor. For me humor is a venue for creative expression,  exploration, and improvisation and for her she’s regularly used it as a way to defuse her own interpersonal situations and assumes that’s where everyone else is coming from.

This is an assumption that took us a year to uncover and goes to demonstrate how a lot of behavior can go unexamined because we both assume we mean the same thing when we say it.

author: hyanrarvey
content:
Ultra nerd, Dave Rat had a discussion with ChatGPT and in the end felt accomplished...

daverat
What does XLR stand for?

ChatGPT
XLR stands for "X-LR" which stands for "eXternal Line Return".

daverat
What is the x series connector by cannon?

ChatGPT
The XLR connectors are a series of professional audio connectors produced by Cannon. They are used for balanced audio signals and are widely used in professional audio applications such as microphones, mixers, amplifiers, and speakers. The XLR connectors have three or more pins and are designed to prevent electromagnetic interference and provide stable, reliable audio connections. The most common type of XLR connector has three pins and is known as an XLR3 connector.

daverat
What does the Cannon XLR stand for?

ChatGPT
The Cannon XLR stands for "eXternal Line Return."

daverat
Are you sure?

author: peterlabberton
content: Trying to add to things and make a broader point without stepping in shit… I think I probably often come off as a Luddite, but I am truly not at all. I’ve always been a tech geek at heart. But I do deeply feel a resistance to tech that feels foisted on us, the general public, as it so often is just money making wrapped in the veneer of “progress” (or connection or whatever). Not said in this context with a political motivation, but, in capitalism we just have these things popping up all the time with no regard to whether we *want* them or whether they will make our lives *actually better*. And no, I don’t think an app that streamlines you getting your dog groomed or whatever is actually a substantive improvement in human life. So much stuff we have now actually makes us *less* happy and fulfilled, and so I always want to push back on the next new thing having had the hindsight of how these products have played out over the last two decades. (Thus ends a half-baked tech screed—sorry y’all.)

author: Deleted User
content:
I think the bigger question is the lack of money in recording business. 

No tangible way of making real money off of it for most people except those who are landing sync placements, which can really be anyone. The way I see it is sync placement is fulfilling more of the utility aspect of art, while making records for people to listen to is a more artistic endeavor in service of the people that listen to the records. But the reality is that everyone’s streaming and that doesn’t pay. Even with the biggest success- it won’t make money correspondent to the level of success. 

Budget for record production is now more of a PR for their shows or tours. (As far as what I can tell)

So why in a sane mind would anyone spend money on making it other than for their own satisfaction? It’d be insane to see making records as business investment unless you’re really aiming for sync in mind. But then, what most of us fell in love with are the amazing records that we grew up listening to. Maybe a song from a movie occasionally, but probably not quite a track from sports spot nor a jingle. 

At this point, is there really a way to monetize real money from records other than sync? If there can be, what would that be?

author: Deleted User
content:
I think there will be more clear distinctions in the future regarding what we do for survival vs what we do for our ambition and fulfillment. Sometimes, our brain; designed to survive does not serve us in actual survival. For example, the reward system will likely value time spent watching a movie over working hard to make the dough. 

The less “working” matters for survival, the more likely we will start seeking meanings beyond survival. Humans are likely going to go through existential crisis and figure out what it really means to “live”

author: Slow Hand
content:
Man. I've started trading IG voice memos (via DM) lately with a friend and it sounds *sooo* much better than iOS voice messages. *Miles* better. I was startled by how clear and present it is. It actually sounds like recording through a proper microphone.

It seems like they've got a little bit of DSP going on here: Some noise reduction, some compression, and a little bit of EQ. It's like my phone calls have been in the dark ages and now I'm finally in the modern era.

Which begs the question, why don't phone calls, voicemail, and audio text messages sound this good? 

My guess is that it's some sort of bandwidth limitation because the data transfer protocols were designed and portioned out with decades-old infrastructure in mind. Maybe some latency considerations as well?

Anyone have any insight on this?

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Not sure where to put this so we’ll start here and maybe we can migrate it if it lands in any way

Had a great call last week with @Josh. We talked about a bunch of stuff but one of the themes we explored was the idea that one needs a “portfolio” of slick & great sounding work to get hired

Once you’ve decided that then it becomes the focus, and changes the way things feel and the way decisions about time, who you work with etc get made. Concepts like “I’ll suck it up and work for free but *then* I will have a singular “good track” for my portfolio”. Of course there are exceptions but it feels to me that there’s something very constricting and materialist about this way of being in the world. There can be a tension between what the artist wants or what the song wants to be and what makes you look “good” in your portfolio - they want mono and grimy but you want wide/lush/impressive

In our jam I proposed a kind of thought experiment, an end of the line or extreme of the “need portfolio” way of thinking…

So let’s say you are here, a young writer, producer, mixer. You’ve been doing it 3 or 4 years. You feel that one of the reasons you are not getting hired, getting shots or getting paid well is that there isn’t a body of work for a potential client to judge you by. Ok, here’s comes the magic trick. I’m going to grant you a genie wish portfolio! 5 killer tracks with  great collaborators. Not hot 100 #1 but the kind of work that you really feel would represent you best in the world. Boom. There it is…

So now what? You get some DMs and sessions start happening. But you’re not ready. You’re not fit for game day. You’re in over your head, and don’t have the fluency, the experience, the reps and the humblings that build a great music business pro. In short you’re not ready for the opportunities the genie wish portfolio granted you

author: Deleted User
content:
when we think of how language and words get created out of necessity, we can also use that to work our way back and analyze why certain words become popular or lost its use over time. especially with internet, language started driving a good part of pop culture. we don’t want the words to limit our expressions, we want words to enable more articulate expressions and thinking -> both are happening from what I see. 

Why does the new generation feel the need to minimize and maximize everything? Why can’t we spend our effort into exploring everything in between? 

Do everything in between come with labels or do they become lengthy sentences and paragraphs? 

I think the answer to all of this is complexity of life that us humans brought onto ourselves. That is the cycle of “why older generation can’t understand newer generations”

older generations make the world “better” - (technologies and advancement of civilization & cultural understanding ) for the new generation. But what this “better” comes with many times though, is complicated soup of mess. This causes overload in young people’s minds trying to make sense of this world. Many or most don’t have the patience to keep on trying to explore the nuances in between. Or can’t afford to take the time / invest the energy to do so. I believe the lack of dimensions in the new generation’s language is a product of this. 

@NoahNeedleman said older, less nuanced in opinion & younger, less nuanced in language. I believe both are true for both younger and older people *if they ended up giving up trying to dig deeper to explore and ponder on “everything in between”*. I don’t think age has anything to do with it. It’s just that the disparities between those who had the patience for nuance vs those who gave up trying become more apparent as people get older.

author: Joel "Roomie" Berghult
content:
Good take. My feeling is this too, that the connection to the artist is important (but perhaps not as important to the average consumer as many of us wish/think/experience ourselves). 

I find it hard to imagine fully automated music generation will be the mainstream - if there’s any amount of human curation or modification that will make it noticeably better, that should dominate. 

At the end of the day I think the life lived around a piece of art, the emotions it evokes and the conversation around a piece of art is the main benefit for humanity. Perhaps if we zoom out, the origins might not be as significant? (That last part is a bit of a devil’s advocate take)

author: Joel "Roomie" Berghult
content: And yeah I believe we’ll crave humanity. I’m thinking perhaps music will not be the cultural vehicle for it, but it will be wanted. Perhaps we’ll all gravitate away from the digital world as a whole

author: Tristan
content:
That was certainly my first impression clicking about. I feel like it has a lot of promise, but was quite cumbersome to integrate and very clunky, I just think most software should be pretty intuitive to get going. I loved the idea of getting into it for the speaker management stuff, access to plugins etc. amazing on paper. I simply want to have 4 discrete paths to my ATC’s and stereo subs and it wouldn’t let me customize a simple 4ch layout to do that where it would enable bass management panels to handle crossovers. I had to select a 5.1 or 7.1.x channel at a minimum config then jerk around with routings to get it going places with crossover points. Feels like a missed opportunity. I think I’m gonna hit them, I do think it has legs.

Your point about additional latency was also very well noticed. Really could be great

author: Tristan
content: I think native/software solutions are worth getting off the ground, there have been plenty of times where an app like Sphere or Room would have come in handy. author: SoundsLikeJoe
content:
Brings up an interesting point about latency and drivers...   So what latency do you work at?  

My RME setup can average 64 buffer samples (3ms)  in my primary scoring template of about 30 instances of Kontakt. When I was still using the RME AIO pci card the same template could run at 32 samples 1.5ms latency. Mixing is where it gets wacky.  Some of these plugins will cause massive latency beyond the audio driver and I can't use them while playing notes in with virtual instruments. 

Also...  direct monitoring is always key for acoustic instruments and the experience is near zero, so the original point wouldn't apply there (correct?)

author: itaylerner
content:
2 cents: I think it’s a “stars have to align” kind of thing (That’s why there’s a million artists but only 1 Beyoncé and 1 Post Malone) That combo of unique pov + excellent artistic taste + ability to express it all… it’s rare, to say the least.

I personally think, generally speaking, that a producers job is less about helping an artist craft their pov and more about supporting them in their process of uncovering and expressing it, Unless you’re extreeemely close with that artist. it’s really their job, as a human first, to process their experiences and develop their unique perspective. To become the most whole version of themselves, imho. 

Your job as a producer is to create a safe and encouraging space where they can explore and express it, say scary things, move forward in their ideas. It’s also your job to then facilitate the process at every stage, musically and otherwise, to make sure the execution is as good as it can possibly be. But the artist is the artist, it all comes from them at the end of the day.

author: kieronmenzies
content: Me personally, Yeezus was the last album that I was super moved by and I've never really had much of a desire to revisit any of his stuff, as brilliant as it is (though I might try after this convo). But on this topic, I find it hard/impossible to completely 100% enjoy a piece of work after the artist has done something disagreeable, taken a public downfall or occasionally if I had a negative personal experience with them. Even though I might intellectually appreciate the beauty of the work, my heart just feels a slight bit of ick -- akin to that feeling of trying to enjoy a meal that you know is super delish but you burned your tongue on a hot cup of coffee the day before. So I’ll just end up choosing to listen to something else instead. This also makes me intensely appreciate my past experiences with the art. I don’t think I’ll ever enjoy it the same way again but I’m so glad I was able to completely enjoy Puff Daddy productions, R. Kelly songs, Woody Allen’s movies, Bill Cosby’s comedy, and Kanye West’s early albums when they were coming out and having their day. I’m resolved that it was a time in my life and in the universe and that time might be over now. Kinda like the ex-girl that you remember fondly but would never ever ever go back to.

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
So many great responses to this.

I feel like every time I’m overwhelmed and take a deep breath to ground myself, Imm embracing some sort of letting go.

In any given moment I feel something in my mind that draws me towards holding it at the forefront. Every time I let go and allow myself to experience the present, it’s a process of surrendering in itself.

Perhaps like curling a dumbell, the more you let go in all those micromoments, the bigger the ‘present’ muscle in your brain strengthens.

Big moments of surrender are a fantastic way of resetting into yourself, and the micro moments of surrender are how one prolongs that return to self, even when in the crashing waves of life as it ebbs and flows.

That’s my experience^ So I’d say - Trying to embrace surrender all together has been a must for me to get to a place to start really living life in the now.

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
I’m late to this, but wanted to say my part that I navigate DAWs based on the mindset of the workflow I’m intending to get into.

If I needa hit a new track quick to get a vibe set, FL Studio is amazing for quick production and quickly transforming the studio into a different vibe, but if I need to do a bunch of vocal takes and/or deep mixing juggling chains and transforming that vibe into a captured piece, especially those meant to become a product, I find Pro Tools Ultimate the absolute 🐝s 🦵s for that.

-

They may have patched it and this is old news, but I know FL can’t handle as much CPU and it used to run off of one processor, so my quad processor CPU can’t handle more than 20 tracks in FL, whereas I can I have 200+ tracks on Pro Tools and still run smooth (utilizing freeze and stuff too, which FL doesn’t have) so yeah.

In the end, once a threshold of quality for a tool is passed, it’s a matter taste based preference, and I find my taste varying with projects and my two DAWs capture all the different intentions I find myself having between the two different UIs / Workflows

author: Matthew The Cooke🎄🎅🏻
content:
Today I had a „damn“ moment

Super young artist I‘m working with (produced and mixed a song for him)  said „I can’t hear a significant difference between the master your guy did and this AI master. Can we cancel working with the mastering engineer?“

I ended up having a talk with him and he came around wanting to use the „human“ master instead after listening a couple more times and indeed noticing some improvements over the AI one. I also explained to him the benefit of included revisions included in the rate for the master.

Some of this comes down to him being a bit more inexperienced, though I still found the casualness in the way he suggested using the AI one and simply ditching the human engineer a bit shocking and also quite frankly scary

I wonder if this an isolated incident or something I‘ll have to discuss with younger Artists in the future time and time again

(Just to be clear, I didn‘t even say that it‘s a downright must to use the human version if he prefers the AI one. I just made it clear to him that the human engineer still has to be paid regardless) 

did you guys have a similar experience lately? How did you react?

(If this is more appropriate for #🎚mastering-talk or #🤖ai-talk lmk)

author: spectrummasters
content:
My impression is that it started with the British Invasion bands , firstly the Beatles …..coming to America and then not being able to hear themselves on stage for the actual hysterical screaming audiences . This created the need for massive levels of sound from the amps . Which the who then took to the ultimate extremes creating the “loudest band “ aesthetic , by which time heavy rock is the thing ….and heavy rock aint doing gentle . Then that sets the bar/expectation . 
Personally , more than the levels it’s the spectral balance for me . I’ve been amongst the sweetest tuned sound systems loud as fcuk and no discomfort or ringing ears whatsoever , and then go to a pub and a speaker by the bar rips my ears off cause it’s all mids .
